sentence: I run a marathon twice a year. (run)
I ran a marathon last year. (run)
I will run a marathon next year. (run)
I eat lunch in my office. (eat)
I ate lunch an hour ago. (eat)
I will eat lunch in one hour. (eat)
I see a movie once a week. (see)
I saw a movie yesterday. (see)
I will see a movie tomorrow. (see)
I know it. (know)
I knew it the day before yesterday. (know)
I will know it by tomorrow. (know)
I learn English. (learn)
I learned English the last two years. (learn)
I will learn English next year. (learn)
I cook my supper every night. (cook)
I cooked our dinner already. (cook)
I will cook breakfast tomorrow. (cook)
I have run several marathons this year. (run)
I had run many marathons in the past. (run)
I will have run a marathon by the time I turn 30. (run)
I have learned a lot about English grammar this semester. (learn)
I had learned the basics of English grammar in elementary school. (learn)
I will have learned a lot about English grammar when I finish college. (learn)
I have known her since I was young. (know)
I had known her until she passed away. (know)
I will have known her for 20 years next month. (know)
I have cooked supper every night this week. (cook)
I had cooked supper every night until the stove broke. (cook)
I will have cooked supper every night by the time this diet ends. (cook)
It has been raining, and the street is still wet. (rain)
I have been running, and I am still tired. (run)
She has been practicing the piano, and she is much better now. (practice)
It had been raining, and the street was still wet. (rain)
I had been running, and I was still tired. (run)
She had been practicing the piano, and she had gotten much better. (practice)
By tonight, it will have been raining several hours, and the street will be very wet. (rain)
By next summer, I will have been running for almost a year, and I will be fit and healthy. (run)
By the time of the concert, she will have been practicing the piano for several months, and she will be much better. (practice)
